stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on UV mapping and texturing for Course 13, a large ice castle level. He also discussed significant performance gains from the new FBDX3 microcode, his future YouTube content plans, and the collaborative art process with Biobak.

development_findings.summary: A major technical discovery was made: with optimized memory traffic, the N64's RSP (Reality Signal Processor) becomes the primary performance bottleneck, not the RDP or fillrate as commonly believed.
development_findings.quote: we found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor. Now, if you actually optimize your game well.

development_findings.summary: The integration of Sauraen's new FBDX3 microcode has resulted in a significant performance boost, with the game approaching 60 FPS even in complex, unoptimized scenes.
development_findings.quote: it's basically like 50 FPS now. And I haven't even limited the drawing distance again.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is planning to release a demo of only Course 1 to allow players to test the new camera and Mario controls.
The team is experiencing a temporary issue in Course 13 where they are running out of memory for collision triangles, which will be resolved once a proper collision map is implemented.
Course 13 is designed to be a large, labyrinthine castle with multiple interconnected paths and secret areas to encourage exploration.
There is an unresolved bug where ambient light disappears when Mario is near a secondary light source, which seems specific to the X2 microcode version used on emulators.
Kaze briefly showcased a separate project where Banjo-Kazooie levels are ported into the Mario 64 engine, featuring a one-to-one port of the original renderer and 120 completed stars.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels new financial pressure due to having a child, which is pushing him to create more YouTube content and consider strategies he feels are 'selling out'.
context_findings.quote: now that I have a child, I need to make more money. So that means a lot more YouTube content. But it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes evoking a specific emotion in the player (e.g., 'cold and mysterious' for the ice level) over purely aesthetic appeal.
context_findings.quote: when I'm doing visuals, I don't really think about it in terms of like pleasure to look at. That's like secondary to me. For me, I think about it in first line about like emotions I want to invoke in the player.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the best way to truly learn programming is to start with a low-level language like MIPS Assembly to understand the fundamentals before moving to high-level languages.
context_findings.quote: if you really, really want to get into programming, is to learn with MIPS Assembly. And then after you learn MIPS Assembly, you will look at C and you'll be like, why did I ever think this would need to be learned?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses strong disdain for being compared to Elon Musk, whom he considers a 'fraud'.
context_findings.quote: He's comparing me to Elon Musk? That fraud? I'm so much smarter than Elon Musk and I invented way better electric cars.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a long, satirical, and dark-humored idea about creating a fake persona on an alt account and then 'exposing' it on his main channel to gain YouTube views, highlighting his awareness of and contempt for online drama culture.

biobak.summary: Kaze's workflow involves creating a functional level with placeholder visuals, which he considers a 'suggestion' for Biobak to then elevate into the final, polished art.
biobak.quote: I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

biobak.summary: Kaze and Biobak have a strong collaborative dynamic where Biobak intuits the intended 'feeling' of a level, leading to a smooth creative process without major issues.
biobak.quote: It's usually just the overall feeling I want to keep but so far we never ran into an issue with that. And you know what the feeling is, you are here in the streams, I imagine you know exactly what I'm looking for.

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating assets for the outside area of Course 13.
Zeina also cuts Kaze's hair, showcasing an intersection of their personal and professional lives.
zeina.quote: Yes, Zeina haircut. I'm not paying for a haircut. I'm making Zeina do it.

key_stories.title: The FBDX3 Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: A new microcode from contributor Sauraen dramatically improved the game's framerate. This breakthrough also led to the discovery that for an optimized game, the N64's true performance bottleneck is the RSP, challenging long-held assumptions in the development community.
key_stories.challenge: The game was suffering from performance issues common to complex N64 projects, struggling to maintain a high framerate.
key_stories.process: Contributor Sauraen developed a new microcode, FBDX3. Kaze integrated and tested it, discovering that not only did it dramatically improve performance, but it also revealed that the RSP, not the RDP, was now the main performance bottleneck.
key_stories.outcome: The game now runs at nearly 60 FPS in demanding areas, and the team's understanding of N64 performance has fundamentally shifted, allowing for more targeted optimization efforts.
key_stories.key_quote: we found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor. Now, if you actually optimize your game well.

key_stories.title: Kaze and Biobak's Artistic Workflow
key_stories.summary: Kaze described his artistic collaboration with Biobak. Kaze creates the level's functional blockout and emotional blueprint, which serves as a 'suggestion' for Biobak, who then transforms it into the final polished art, demonstrating a workflow built on deep trust and clear roles.
key_stories.challenge: Creating a compelling and cohesive visual style for a large level (Course 13) that Kaze himself felt was visually 'boring' in its initial state.
key_stories.process: Kaze focuses on building the level's functional layout and establishing a core emotional theme ('cold and mysterious'). He implements placeholder geometry and textures, which he explicitly frames as a 'suggestion' for the artist, Biobak.
key_stories.outcome: A clear and effective artistic workflow is established where Kaze trusts Biobak to interpret his foundational work and deliver a final, high-quality visual experience that matches the intended emotion.
key_stories.key_quote: I have resigned myself to like knowing that whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

key_stories.title: The Pressure to 'Sell Out'
key_stories.summary: Faced with new financial responsibilities as a father, Kaze is grappling with how to grow his YouTube channel. He satirizes popular but creatively bankrupt content trends while admitting he may have to 'sell out a little bit,' revealing the classic conflict between artistic integrity and financial reality.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze is facing increased financial pressure after the birth of his child and needs to find ways to increase his income.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided he needs to make more videos. He then brainstormed a satirical, dark-humored scheme to manufacture YouTube drama for views, highlighting his awareness and disdain for such content while simultaneously acknowledging the financial pressure to potentially 'sell out'.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze is planning to increase his YouTube output but is conflicted about it. He is struggling with the idea of compromising his creative integrity to appeal to broader, drama-focused YouTube trends for financial stability.
key_stories.key_quote: now that I have a child, I need to make more money. So that means a lot more YouTube content. But it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.

open_questions.context: Kaze asserts that with the new FBDX3 microcode, the primary performance bottleneck has shifted from the RDP/memory to the RSP, a conclusion he says another developer also reached.
questions: Can you walk us through the moment you realized the bottleneck had shifted? What did the performance counters look like?
What does optimizing for the RSP look like in practice, and how does it differ from traditional N64 optimization techniques?
How does this fundamental shift in understanding performance affect your design philosophy for future levels?

open_questions.context: Kaze describes his artistic workflow with Biobak as him providing a 'suggestion' and Biobak making it 'look a lot better,' stating they've never had a major issue.
questions: Can you describe a time when Biobak took one of your 'suggestions' in a completely unexpected direction that you loved?
What does the feedback loop look like? How do you communicate an abstract 'feeling' to Biobak to guide his work?
Has there ever been a creative disagreement, even a minor one, and how did you resolve it to get to a better final product?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is creating assets for the outside area of Course 13.
questions: What kind of assets is Zeina creating for the outside area, and how do they contribute to the level's theme?
How do you and Zeina collaborate on a space? Does she have creative freedom, or are you providing specific direction?
How do you navigate the dynamic of being both creative partners on a major project and a married couple?

open_questions.context: Kaze plans to release a small demo of just Course 1 so players can test the new camera and Mario controls.
questions: What specific changes to the camera and controls are you most excited for players to experience?
What kind of feedback will be most valuable from this targeted demo?
What's the strategic reason for releasing this small demo now, rather than waiting for a larger portion of the game to be ready?
